name.text: Types of comments

questiontext.text: Match the type of comment with the correct comment structure.

subquestion.text: Used to enclose single or multiline comments. These comments are appropriate at the beginning of a program to describe the application.
Used for adding a comment to the end of a statement or to create a single line comment.

Used for documentation. The javadoc tool copies these comments into a separate HTML document to create an instructional manual or external documentation. Documentation comments are appropriate for describing a class or method.

name.text: Object Oriented Programming
Platform Independent

questiontext.text: If a program is "platform independent", it is

answer.text: able to run on any Operating System.
able to use commands from various programming languages to create an application.
not supported by any particular company such as Microsoft or Apple.

name.text: public class CatInTheHat { public static void main(String args) { System.out.println("good-bye"); System.out.print("adios\n");

questiontext.text:
public class CatInTheHat {

      public static void main(String [] args) {
            System.out.print("Cat");
            System.out.println("in\n");
            System.out.print("the\nhat");
      }
}

CatInTheHat produces output similar to:

name.text: public class MulticulturalGoodbye { public static void main(String args) { System.out.println("good-bye"); System.out.print("adios\n");

questiontext.text:
public class MulticulturalGoodbye {

      public static void main(String[] args) {
            System.out.println("Good-bye");
            System.out.print("adios\n");
            System.out.println("au voire");
      }
}

MulticulturalGoodbye produces output similar to:

name.text: To display a double quotation mark (") as part of string output,

questiontext.text: To display a double quotation mark (") as part of string output,

answer.text: place the double quotation mark within double quotation marks (").
place the double quotation mark within a comment.
precede the double quotation mark with a single quotation mark ( ' ). Note: Precede means to put it in front.
precede the double quotation mark with a back slash (\).

name.text: What effect does \n have when included in an output string?

questiontext.text: What effect does \n have when included in an output string?

answer.text: Output is moved to the next line.
A \n is displayed in the output.
A tab (8 spaces) is displayed in the output.
A N is displayed in the output.

name.text: What effect does \t have when included in an output string?

questiontext.text: What effect does \t have when included in an output string?

answer.text: Output is moved to the next line.
A \t is displayed in the output.
A tab (8 spaces) is displayed in the output.
A T is displayed in the output.

name.text: Which describes the output displayed by the statement: System.out.format("%-10s %-10s %8s", "Item", "Quantity", "Cost\n");

questiontext.text:
Which describes the output displayed by the statement:
System.out.format("%-10s %-10s %8s", "Item", "Quantity", "Cost\n");

answer.text: Item and Quantity will be right aligned, Cost will be left aligned.
Item and Quantity will be left aligned, Cost will be right aligned.
Item, Quantity, and Cost will be right aligned.
Item, Quantity, and Cost will be left aligned.

void

name.text: Which is not true about a syntax error?

questiontext.text: Which is not true about a syntax error?

answer.text: A syntax error will stop the application from compiling.
A syntax error is caused by a violation of the rules of Java.
A syntax error indicates improper spaces in the code.
A syntax error must be corrected and the program recompiled before the program will run.

an output error
a syntax error
an argument

name.text: Which of the following represent correctly-formed comments?

questiontext.text:
Which of the following represent correctly-formed comments?

  I. // Happy
  II. /* Sorry /*
  III. /* Wise */

answer.text: I only
I and II only
I and III only
III only
